ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class taught me a lot about Pliny the Elder and Pliny the Younger and improved my Latin ability as well. The two authors have different styles and I learned to read both well. We also got some good context about the authors' contemporaries and the Roman political scene throughout their lifetimes.
Just a lot about the Plinys as authors, as well as the historical/cultural context surrounding their works. Also a lot of Latin analytical skills from a more literature/civilization standpoint!
This course was perfect practice to translate prose; up tot his point, I had mostly translated poetry or read prose in translation.

This course improved my Latin-reading abilities to some extent, but I believe that the most important skill I learned was to understand how to bring different sources from the ancient world into conversation with each other. Previous Latin courses that I had taken only focused on single works or authors, and the level of historical and literary depth in the Plinies was new to me.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: translation in class was not mandatory, which I thought was a strength overall. Class discussions were usually very lively and engaging. The professor and TA were both very knowledgeable. The selected readings and selected articles were quite engaging. Weaknesses: workload was sometimes on the heavy side, but that is overall dependent on the person.

Strengths: just very knowledgeable and engaging professor and teaching assistant, great selection of readings and supporting scholarship, very cool final paper/presentations, enriching discussion
Weaknesses: at times workload was a little high, but good for challenging me and pushing me to improve translation skills! Readings always made sense together under distinct themes and had a progression, but yes - maybe slightly less readings.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The online discussion board was a great idea. I hope this continues beyond the pandemic as well.
Pretty much most things succeeded - zoom discussions flowed smoothly and included all!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It's definitely an interesting course and gives you a lot of insight into Roman politics in the first century. The Plinies are difficult, especially Pliny the Elder, but you will learn a lot. I would probably not recommend this to a student coming out of L3/L4 or a bridge course unless they are particularly advanced, but other than that, I think it's a great option.
Absolutely! The Plinys are essential parts of Roman literature and it's a great way to enrich your understanding not just of Latin, but also of Roman civilization.
Yes, but only if you are confident in ability to handle lugubrious passages of sometimes difficult prose.

I would recommend this course to any student who is seriously interested in engaging with the ancient world on its own terms. As opposed to courses that simply deal with mechanics of language or solitary literary works, this course forced the students to become immersed in a variety of cultural attitudes about an astonishing number of subjects - really the joy of classics itself in my opinion.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Canvas discussions tabs, online quizzes, occasional asynchronous readings

LATN 729 01/LATN 429 01
